label.text: Plate Tectonics
Earth’s outermost surface is made from a rigid layer called the crust which lies above a partially molten layer of rock.
Plate tectonics is a theory about how the crust is divided into large sections called ‘plates’ and how these plates move relative to each other.
Using GPS measurements, the speed and direction of movement of the plates can be estimated. GPS measurements are conducted at different stations across the world.

The map shows the boundaries between the tectonic plates. The white circles show the location of different measurement stations that are attached to Earth and move with the tectonic plate they are on.

The length of the arrows shows the speed of movement of these stations and the orientation of the arrow shows the direction in which they move. The longer the arrow, the faster the measured movement is in the direction indicated by the arrow. ‌‌

North America
Europe
Asia
Australia
Antarctica
Africa
South America
tectonic plate boundary
location of GPS measurement station
direction of tectonic plate movement; arrow length indicates speed
mountain range
The most earthquakes and the largest earthquakes occur near where two tectonic plates meet.
There are five locations marked on the map from A to E.
Which of the five locations have a relatively high risk of earthquakes, and which have a relatively low risk of earthquakes?
Select ‘Low risk’ or ‘High risk’ for each location.
A
B
C
D
E
Lystrosaurus is an extinct land-dwelling animal that lived between 200 and 300 million years ago. Fossils of this animal have been found in Africa, Antarctica and India.
The images show what scientists think Lystrosaurus probably looked like, and fossil remains of part of the skull and lower jaw of Lystrosaurus.
How do the fossil findings of Lystrosaurus support the theory of plate tectonics?
Three types of movement are possible at the boundary between two tectonic plates: the plates can slide apart from each other, grind past each other, or slide towards each other.
The figure below shows the three types of movement of the outermost surface (crust) on top of the partially molten layer of rock.
Plate boundary where plates slide apart from each other
Plate boundary where plates grind past each other
Plate boundary where plates slide towards each other
crust
direction of crust movement
partially molten rock
direction of molten rock movement
Depending upon the type of movement, different geological phenomena occur at the plate boundaries, such as the formation of mountain ranges and new seabeds.
Select the option that describes the process leading to these geological formations.
mountain ranges
new seabed
